stem: A 19-year-old male with a history of a blunt chest trauma is suddenly gasping for air. Based on the documentation in the Thoracic Imaging & Airway Alignment tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute respiratory failure and hemodynamic collapse.
Background: MVA involving steering wheel impact 2 hours ago. Rib fractures noted on admission.
Assessment: Severe respiratory distress; jugular venous distention (JVD) present.
Recommendation: Immediate decompression.

tabs.title: Thoracic Imaging & Airway Alignment
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemFindingClinical Indication
Breath SoundsAbsent on Right; Hyper-resonant to percussionAir trapped in pleural space
Tracheal PositionDeviated to the LEFTLATE sign of tension
Chest X-ray (Bedside)Right-sided lung collapse; Mediastinal shiftTension Pneumothorax
Venous StatusDistended Neck Veins (JVD)Obstructive Shock component

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 78/40, HR 148, RR 36, SpO2 76% on RA (dropping fast).

actionOptions.text: Prepare the client for emergent needle decompression
Administer IV Heparin bolus as prescribed
Assess the client for Homan's sign in the lower extremities

parameterOptions.text: Presence of a friction rub on heart auscultation

rationale.correct: Tension Pneumothorax (c2) is a life-threatening medical emergency. The air trapped in the pleural space increases pressure, causing JVD, tracheal deviation to the opposite side, and cardiovascular collapse (Hypotension/Tachycardia). Immediate action involves decompressing the pressure (a1) and maximizing oxygenation (a2). Monitoring for tracheal midline return (p1) and the return of breath sounds (p2) validates the success of decompression.
clinicalPearls: JVD occurs in Tension Pneumothorax because the high intrathoracic pressure prevents blood from returning to the heart.
A needle is placed in the 2nd intercostal space, mid-clavicular line for decompression.
Wait for a 'Hiss' soundâ€”that indicates the tension is released.

questionTrap.trap: Waiting for a Chest X-ray before acting.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Tension pneumothorax is a CLINICAL diagnosis. If the trachea is shifted and the BP is tanking, act immediately. Do not wait for the film.

mnemonic.title: Tension Clues
mnemonic.expansion: S-Shift (Trachea). H-Hyper-resonance. I-Increased JVD. F-Filtered sounds (Absent). T-Tanking BP.
